Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: WebAuthn
  • Specification or proposal URL (if available): https://w3c.github.io/webauthn/#publickey-credentials-create-feature
  • Explainer URL (if available):
  • Proposal author(s) (@-mention GitHub accounts): @stephenmcgruer
  • Caniuse.com URL (optional):
  • Bugzilla URL (optional):
  • Mozillians who can provide input (optional):

Other information

Hello Mozilla friends :)

I'm requested a formal standards position on the ability to create a credential in a cross-origin iframe in WebAuthn. This was added to the spec in w3c/webauthn#1801, after having been discussed in w3c/webauthn#1656 as well as in WebAuthn Working Group meetings.

This feature allows web developers to create WebAuthn credentials (that is, "publickey" credentials, aka passkeys) in cross-origin iframes. This will allow developers to create passkeys in embedded scenarios, such as after an identity step-up flow where the Relying Party is providing a federated identity experience. Two conditions are required for this new ability, for security reasons:

  1. The iframe has a publickey-credentials-create-feature permission policy.
  2. The iframe has transient user activation.
items.title: WebAuthn: Allow for credential creation in a cross-origin iframe

Other information

The main goal of this feature is to provide web authors a mechanism to track and control the position of the Window object.

The feature would probably involve both, the HTML spec and the CSSOM View Module which defines the Window's attributes exposed to describe its size and position.

There is an ongoing discussion in the CSS issue 7693 about potential approaches for its implementation and the most appropriated standard venue.

items.content_html:
Request for Mozilla Position on an Emerging Web Specification

  • Specification title: Media Capture and Streams Extensions, section MediaStreamTrack Statistics and specifically the MediaStreamTrackAudioStats subsection.
  • Specification or proposal URL: https://w3c.github.io/mediacapture-extensions/#dom-mediastreamtrackaudiostats
  • Proposal author(s): @henbos
  • Mozillians who can provide input: @padenot @jan-ivar

This request related to the track.stats API for when MediaStreamTrack is an audio track sourced from getUserMedia. The API shape is the same as for video (previous standards-position: #895) but audio tracks has a separate interface defined for the metrics since these definitions are specific to audio: MediaStreamTrackAudioStats.

The motivation for this API is to monitor quality, on an individual basis, e.g. a user of a web app is experiencing quality issues, which part of the pipeline is responsible or is it caused by the device needs to be debugged using metrics from the wild specific to that app and user, and for A/B testing, for example understanding how rolling out features in video conferencing web app affect the quality of the users of that web app. The latency metric may additionally be used by a web app as input for example to WebAudio which may aid audio processing use cases, but this is also useful as a quality indicator too.

So there are two types of metrics exposed by this API:

  1. Audio frame counters and duration, including frames delivered and total frames. This allows calculating dropped frames (or frames duration) as "dropped = total - delivered". This allows estimating glitches, such device connectivity issues (e.g. poor bluetooth connection), the OS or user agent is dropping frames or other device issues. It is important to have this in JS because issues like this typically happen in the wild rather than in lab conditions.
  2. Microphone input latency. This is always useful and I believe @padenot has said that web developers have been asking for this for years? At the time of writing latency has been merged into the spec but the PR that adds min/max/avg latency is still in review: w3c/mediacapture-extensions#134 (Update: the resolution from last meeting is to adopt the PR).

Mozilla has expressed interest in latency but has opposed measuring audio drops, see below for history and more information.

Other information

  • The dropped frames disagreement was discussed in the September WebRTC WG meeting (link with timestamp) where no consensus was reached.
  • w3c/mediacapture-extensions#129 is the issue for the disagreement, which adds some information to the discussion, including how device connectivity can cause glitches before audio reaches the UA. This issue is still open.
  • The blink-dev Intent to Prototype shows support from GoTo, Teams and Zoom.
items.title: MediaStreamTrack Statistics (Audio)
